title: Man, 28, attacked grandfather in his bed after he was released from hospital to self-medicate
text:
The family of a retired police officer have slated the justice system after the man who brutalised the 77 year old with a hammer may soon be able to walk the streets.

John Clowes was attacked while in bed in his sheltered housing unit in Stoke-on-Trent last year.

Simba Muguti, 28, also of Stoke-on-Trent made his way into his house last October, when he beat him repeatedly with a hammer.

Mr Clowes suffered a severed left ear, head injuries, loss of blood, a black eye - leaving him permanently scarred.

John Clowes, 77, from Stoke-on-Trent was attacked in his own assisted living unit after an unprovoked attacker broke in

Brutalised: John Clowes was left with a severed left ear, head injuries, loss of blood and a black eye, the incident has left him permanently scarred

Despite the vicious nature of the attack, Muguti was found not guilty by reason of insanity and was remanded to a psychiatric hospital.

But Mr Clowes's family were left disgusted after recently receiving a letter saying that Muguti had made progress in the hospital and would soon be allowed to two hours of accompanied leave each week.

Outraged granddaughter, Donna Flynn, aged 36 from Clayton, said: 'When police detained Muguti it took six police officers and they had to Taser him twice in the heart to get him down and now he will be out on the streets with just two members of staff.'

'In court we were told that he would be detained in hospital indefinitely. Never did we think he'd be allowed back into the community less than a year after the attack.'

'When he attacked my granddad he had been released from Harplands Hospital six weeks earlier to self medicate because they said he was safe to leave.'

Disbelief: Donna Flynn, Jennifer Clowes and Barbara Morris (left to right) have been left outraged after receiving notification Muguti will be allowed back on the streets

The assisted living unit in Clayton, Stoke-on-Trent where Muguti carried out the attack on Mr Clowes

'We feel completely and utterly let down by the justice system. How can somebody like that be released back into the public for two hours a week?'

'My dad was a serving police officer and this is how he's being repaid.'

The family received the letter from the Ministry of Justice on September 9. It came just 11 months after Muguti carried out the attack on October 14 last year.

John's wife Jennifer Clowes says the night of the attack was like a 'horror film'.

The 74-year-old, who has since moved to Baldwins Gate with husband John, said:

'John has dementia and I've had to tell him that Muguti is going to be released and now he's convinced that he is going to come after him. It's brought it all back.'

Barbara Morris, John's neighbour, who was also targeted by Muguti, has also been 'gutted' by the latest news.

She said: 'At the trial they said he could be dismissed from attending the proceedings because they believed if he heard what had happened it would cause him to react, so how can somebody who was like that five months ago now be allowed in public?'
description: GRAPHIC CONTENT: An 'insane' man from Stoke-on-Trent who brutalised retired police officer, John Clowes, 77, will soon walk the streets again after being granted accompanied leave.
